name: Bayesian Models in Philosophy of Science
abstract: Bayesian models are at the core of various successful research programs in philosophy of science and formal epistemology: they are used for reconstructing and better understanding scientific reasoning, but also for developing foundational theories of belief and decision-making under uncertainty. This symposium investigates how foundational and model-based conceptions of Bayesianism relate to each other, and how they might cross-fertilize each other. More specifically, we address this general question from three perspectives: theories of valid inductive inference, understanding Bayesian models as scientific models, and comparing Bayesian models to competitors. At the end, we combine these perspectives to explain the popularity of Bayesianism in various fields of philosophy and science.
subs: Modeling Limitations versus the Limitations of a Model|Bayesian Philosophy of Science as Scientific Philosophy|Bayes, Here, There, but Not Everywhere|Commentary||
authors: Stephan Hartmann, Christopher Hitchcock, John D Norton, Michael Titelbaum, Jan Sprenger

name: Beyond Explanation: Exploring the Diversity of Neuroscientific Practice
abstract: The philosophy of neuroscience has in recent decades been dominated by discussions of explanation and in particular of mechanistic explanation. This has produced significant insights into the kinds of causal knowledge that neuroscientific experiments can deliver. However, the focus on explanation has also arguably had a distorting effect on the field. For example, it has encouraged the tendency to lump together or subsume all neuroscientific techniques and models of interest under the heading of explanation (see, for example, debates over whether topological or dynamical "explanations" of neural phenomena are really deserving of the name). But the epistemic terrain of neuroscience is far more varied and interesting than this, and it includes knowledge-producing practices that go beyond explanation. Neuroscientific practice includes the development of tools and experimental systems, data analytic techniques, exploratory investigations, formal descriptive frameworks, predictive simulations, and new laboratory phenomena, as well as a host of clinical translational applications. While these may contribute to explanation, they are nevertheless distinct from it. This symposium aims to articulate the social, material, and normative characteristics of these non-explanatory neuroscientific practices, and to chart their interrelations.
subs: The Mirage of Big-Data Phrenology|Exploratory Concept Formation and the Norms of Description in Neuroscientific Discovery|Assessing the Dynamics of Novel Tool Development: The Rodent Operant Touchscreen Chamber as a Case Study |The Predictive Turn In Neuroscience||
authors: Jackie Sullivan, Daniel Weiskopf, Philipp Haueis, Felipe De Brigard

name: Community Engagement as Scientific and Philosophical Practice
abstract: This symposium will explore the potential of philosophy of scientific practice to become involved as a partner with communities active around science-based issues, such as wetland restoration, environmental justice, biodiversity preservation and resilience to climate change. This symposium focuses on the roles philosophers of science can play in these forms of community engagement by asking two questions: 1) How can concepts from philosophy of scientific practice be utilized to inform and support community engagement? 2) How can taking seriously local knowledge generated by community science efforts, inform new directions in philosophy of science?
subs: Abandoning ‘Trust’ to Foster Community Engagement|Interaction and Pluralism in a Conflictual Context|Involved Philosophy: An Initial Framework for Community-Academia Interaction|Climate Resilience and Community Engagement||
authors: Michael Weisberg, Ayelet Shavit, Helen E Longino, Rachel Ankeny

name: Control and Regulation of Biological Mechanisms
abstract: This symposium will address a topic that so far has been little discussed in philosophy of science: how biological mechanisms are controlled and regulated to serve the needs of the organisms in which they occur. Control plays a critical role since, in living organisms, mechanisms typically perform their activities only when they are required to build or maintain the organism and so must do so in different ways under different conditions. This symposium aims to articulate a framework for understanding how biological mechanisms are controlled. The first contributions articulate insights about control by theoretical biologists and cyberneticists in the mid-20th century that have not been fully incorporated into philosophical thinking about mechanisms. One critical insight is that controlled mechanisms require flexible components on which other mechanisms, control mechanisms, can operate. A second is that these control mechanisms are responsive to conditions in the organism or its environment so as to alter flexible components in the controlled mechanisms so that they operate in ways needed by the organism. The later contributions focus on examples of research on control mechanisms, investigating how this research exhibits both similarities and differences to the accounts of mechanism discovery that focus on controlled mechanisms.
subs: Can Control be Accounted for on a Mechanistic Picture?|Basic Forms of Control in Multicellular Systems|Discovering Control Mechanisms Operative on Cytoplasmic Dyneins|||
authors: William Bechtel, Leonardo Bich, Jason Winning

name: Distinctions within Causation: Irreversibility, Coherence, Invariance and Machine-Likeness
abstract: Research in philosophy of causation has traditionally focused on the fundamental question of how to distinguish causation from correlation. In addition to this focus, philosophers and scientists have more recently turned their attention to a new and important topic–how to distinguish among different types of causal relationships. This symposium proposal contributes to this endeavor by analyzing four novel features of type-causal relationships, which have yet to receive significant attention in the literature. These features include: the degree to which causal relationships exhibit (i) [ir]reversibility, (ii) invariance, (iii) coherence, and (iv) machine-likeness. These features are examined in four separate talks (one co-authored), provided by four philosophers and one scientist, who all conduct research on causation and causal reasoning. Each of these talks examine one of the four features above by providing an analysis of how this feature should be understood, what distinction within causation it clarifies, and why this distinction matters to scientific practice, as well as everyday causal reasoning.
subs: Irreversible and Reversible Causation|Representations of Invariance in Human Causal Induction|Coherent Causal Control|Biological Machines: A Sober Defense||
authors: Lauren Ross, James Woodward, Mimi Liljeholm, Arnon Levy, Marcel Weber

name: The Significance of Quantization Procedures
abstract: Philosophers have often ignored or undervalued the importance of the quantization procedures that serve as methods to construct new quantum theories. However, recent decades have seen major developments in the mathematical tools used for quantization within physics communities. In light of these developments, this symposium aims to reassess the status of quantization and investigate its foundational significance. The participants will discuss and compare the variety of mathematical tools that have been developed while exploring their relation with standing philosophical issues. The symposium aims to (i) explore different points of view concerning the relevance of quantization procedures to questions of inter-theoretic reduction between classical and quantum mechanics, (ii) consider how different approaches to understanding the emergence of classical behavior are influenced by background assumptions concerning realism or anti-realism in the interpretation of quantum mechanics, and (iii) probe the extent to which quantization methods can aid in the interpretation and ontology of quantum theories, especially concerning the nature of charge and particles in field theories.
subs: On the Singularity of the Classical Limit|Deformation Quantization and the Emergence of Particles from Quantum Field Theory|Viewing Quantum Charge from the Classical Vantage Point|Decoherence and Deformation Quantization: Complementary or Rival Explanations of Classical Behavior?||
authors: Benjamin Feintzeig, Marian J. R. Gilton, Joshua Rosaler, Jeremy Steeger

name: Transdisciplinary Modeling in Science: Knowledge Without Borders?
abstract: Mathematical models developed to advance knowledge in one scientific discipline are sometimes applied in another to study a different subject matter. This transdisciplinary aspect of scientific modeling has been the center of philosophical discussion concerned with knowledge transfer. While the parlance of "transfer" conveys a conservative process in nature, a growing number of case studies suggests that modifying the body of knowledge or the subject matter to which it applies is indispensable to a satisfactory trans-domain transfer. There is thus a need to address both the conservation and adaptation aspects in the cross-disciplinary transfer of models and their associated knowledge. Tackling this issue, the first two talks clarify and refine notions of "templates" for analyzing model transfer. The last two talks focus on the process and the practice of circulating models as templates across disciplines. On the whole, the five speakers-four philosophers of science and a practicing scientist-present an all-round perspective of how scientists are motivated to transfer models, but also appear to modify the knowledge associated with them in the process.
subs: Transdisciplinary Templates, Models, and Machine Learning|Travelling Waves: Why and How to Diversify the Role of Templates in Transdisciplinary Modelling|Crossing Domains: The Role of the Translator in the Spread of Scientific Innovations |Tinkering with the Vocabulary of Games: from the Economy to Cancer||
authors: Chia-Hua Lin, Paul Humphreys, Catherine Herfeld, Artem Kaznatcheev, Wybo Houkes

name: Modeling the Social Structure of Science
abstract:
Metascientists and philosophers of science are interested in what makes science work as it does. Formal models of scientific practice are one way to do this. In recent years, philosophers of science have been using formal models to investigate the role of incentives, institutions, and communication structures in informing the outcomes of accuracy, efficiency, and equity in science. In parallel, researchers in the metascience movement have also been using formal models to understand the causes and consequences of the replication crisis in the social and biomedical sciences. Both communities have converged, from different trajectories, on the central question: What is the role of the social structure of science in helping and hindering the aims of scientific progress and credibility? 

 

This interdisciplinary symposium will present theses centered around the possibility of studying the social structure of science using formal models and serves to connect active research programs investigating the social epistemology of science. The aim is to provide a presentation of the state-of-the-art of the literature on social epistemology of science and to foster intellectual progress in the field by connecting scholars from diverse backgrounds, including philosophy of science, computer science, cognitive science, and cultural evolutionary theory.
subs: Cumulative Advantage and the Incentive to Commit Fraud in Science|Intervention and Backfire in the Replication Crisis|Scientific Progress and the Courtroom|Community Characteristics and the Spread of Better Scientific Methods|The Dynamics of Journal Prestige|
authors: Cailin O'Connor, Aydin Mohseni, Remco Heesen, Kevin Zollman, Paul Smaldino

name: Opening Up Open Science
abstract:
The open science movement is attracting significant attention from the scientific community in an effort to increase the reliability of science, promote scientific innovation, and make scientific information widely available to non-specialists. It encompasses a wide variety of initiatives, such as publishing in open-access venues, making study data and methods publicly available, pre-registering study designs in trial registries, encouraging the publication of negative as well as positive results, and making peer review reports publicly available.

 

As this movement develops, philosophers of science interested in doing socially engaged work have important opportunities to help shape open science in ways that maximize its strengths and minimize its weaknesses. This symposium focuses especially on four aspects of the open science movement that merit philosophical consideration: the importance of fostering epistemic diversity and pluralistic confrontation within open science, the challenges of implementing pre-registration as a strategy for promoting replicability, the potential for using preprint repositories to certify research quality while promoting openness, and the steps needed to fulfill the open science movement's goal of facilitating better decision making by non-specialists.
subs: Open Science and Epistemic Diversity: Friends or Foes? |Openness About Openness: Why Pre-registration Is Failing and What To Do About It |Certify Pre-Prints|Making Open Science Work for Non-Specialists|Commentary|
authors: Kevin Elliott, Patricia Soranno, Carole Lee, Sabina Leonelli, Felipe Romero

name: Pluralism in Psychiatric Research: Insights from Philosophy of Science
abstract: Pluralism in philosophy of science is committed to the idea that scientific phenomena are complex and that they require multiple theoretical frameworks to be fully explained and intervened upon. Adopting such a pluralistic framework, recent work in feminist philosophy of science as well as in philosophy of medicine has emphasized taxonomic pluralism and the possibility of the coexistence of crosscutting classifications of scientific domains, each of which captures important aspects of the (complex) target of scientific inquiry. This symposium proposal takes cues from these discussions, and explores their implications for the philosophy of psychiatry. Mental disorder is an intricate and multi-dimensional phenomenon that is intimately tied to an individual, their biology, and their social and cultural contexts, warranting multiple explanatory frameworks to enhance psychiatric epistemology. Papers in the symposium will examine how psychiatric knowledge is made by reflecting on taxonomies that are based on biological mechanisms, natural kinds, theoretical causal models, as well as those incorporating patients' perspectives and realities. Rather than presupposing that there is one correct taxonomy for psychiatric disorders, these papers proceed on the assumption that different psychiatric taxonomies track different properties and processes, thereby serving different interests (e.g., explanation, prediction, intervention).
subs: Biological Essentialism and the Projectability of Psychiatric Categories|Pluralism in Psychiatry Encompasses both Natural and Practical Kinds|Pluralism and Progress in Psychiatry|Reclassifying Body Dysmorphic Disorder:  A Causal Model Informed by the Patient’s Perspective|Participatory Intersubjective Objectivity in Psychiatric Epistemology|Commentary
authors: Jonathan Tsou, Serife Tekin, Robyn Bluhm, MIRIAM SOLOMON, Peter Zachar, Muhammad Ali Khalidi, Amy MacKinnon

name: Stability Concepts in Ecology and Their Practical Implications
abstract: Stability is a recurrent theme in ecological disciplines, but it is notoriously difficult to define. It also comes with a rather rich lexical field that includes notions such as equilibrium, balance, resilience, resistance to disturbance, and ecosystem health. Indeed, stability is part of many conceptual frameworks in ecology and as such, it shapes how researchers apprehend and describe their target system. Perhaps unsurprisingly, debates surrounding this notion are also quite diverse. Many have debated how to define and measure various forms of stability, others have discussed whether it is present or absent in ecological entities, and yet others have endorsed it, sometimes implicitly, as a value in ecological management. The papers in this session will introduce debates in ecology and environmental science that illustrate the centrality of this notion; how it has and still shapes ecological practices and values in important ways.
subs: Spatial Stability Is an Ecological Stability Concept We Need|Different Meaning in Different Sizes: Ecology in Size Scales |From Risk to Resilience in Environmental Impact Assessment|Ecosystem Stability, Equilibrium or Resilience Are Not Sufficient for Ecosystem Health|Stability and Land Health|
authors: Eric Desjardins, Dr. Tamar Schneider, Antoine C. Dussault, Roberta L Millstein, Christopher Eliot

name: From Bosons to Markets to Black Holes: New Prospects for Analogical Reasoning
abstract: Analogical reasoning has a long history in science, but has played a particularly prominent role in examples involving physics recently, from particle to condensed matter to black hole physics, as well as econophysics. These cases appear to raise new philosophical questions about arguments from analogy. Is analogue confirmation possible? That is, is it possible for an experiment on an analogue system to confirm hypotheses about an unmanipulable and inaccessible target system? Can formal analogies alone deliver useful information about a target system? How and under what circumstances? These issues will be examined both from a general philosophical perspective and on the basis of recent scientific practice. Comparisons will be made to uses of analogies in archaeology, evolutionary biology, medicine, and economics.
subs: Prospects for Analogue Confirmation|On the Limits of Experimental Knowledge|The Methodological Novelty of Formal Analogical Reasoning in Quantum Theories|Analogical Reasoning in Econophysics||
authors: Paul Bartha, Patricia Palacios, Doreen Fraser, Dominik Hangleiter

name: The Major Transitions in Cognitive Evolution
abstract: As we come to appreciate the wealth and diversity of intelligences, the challenge becomes how to make sense of this complexity. How can we comprehend it in a systematic way? In this symposium, we explore the idea that one important piece of the puzzle involves treating the evolution of cognition as a series of major transitions. Each transition involved a qualitative change in information flow within nervous systems. Each transition opened up new cognitive capacities, while transforming the power and scope of existing cognitive functions. We consider several aspects of the major transitions framework: the role of learning, brain size, and resource constraints on the evolution of nervous systems; the relationship between major transitions and behavioral innovation; and the implications of major transitions on methods in psychology. This symposium contributes to contemporary debates in general philosophy of science, philosophy of biology and philosophy of cognitive science while drawing on work in evolutionary biology, computational neuroscience and comparative psychology.
subs: Cognition with Large and Small Brains|Mapping out the Landscape: A Multi-Dimensional Approach to Behavioural Innovation|Associative Learning as a Null Model|Explaining Neural Transitions through Resource Constraints||
authors: Andrew Barron, Colin Klein, Rachael Brown, Marta Halina

name: Transformative Experience for Choice and Belief
abstract: The problem of transformative experiences for decision theoretic frameworks was raised by L. A. Paul in 2014. Paul challenges our ability to discern the utilities of the outcomes for many important life decisions, and which utilities to take as relevant. Concurrently in decision theory circles, there have been efforts to develop Bayesian models of belief and preference change to accommodate a kind of transformation: during deliberation we can come to entertain new propositions which were previously inconceivable to us. This symposium focuses on the intersection of the two fields: the problem of indeterminate utilities, and belief revision in models where the state space is refined or expanded.
subs: L. A. Paul’s Transformative Experience: Mentalism and Imagination in Decision Theory|The Transformative Experience of Education|Awareness Growth and the Limits of Rational Planning|Awareness of Unawareness When Unknowns Are Not Simply Unknowns||
authors: Saira Khan, Richard Pettigrew, Marie-Louise Viero, Katie Steele, H. Orri Stefansson

name: Animal Consciousness and Welfare
abstract:
Animal consciousness and animal welfare research are both emerging fields, with important overlap in methods and subject matter. Research into animal consciousness can tell us about the experiences of animals, as well as help us understand more about the evolution and functioning of our own minds. However, it also has important ethical implications, as conscious experience grounds animal welfare considerations. The ways in which we understand animal consciousness, and which animals we take to possess consciousness, will affect our moral decision-making as it regards animals.

This symposium brings together researchers from around the world, working in both philosophy and science, to examine how our understanding of the evolution and functioning of animal consciousness can inform the theory and practice of animal welfare.
subs: Two Paths to Skepticism about Animal Consciousness|Animal Consciousness and Animal Welfare|Felt Unpleasantness and the Measurement of Animal Suffering|Integrating Animal Consciousness into Welfare|Welfare and Animal Culture|
authors: Heather Browning, Jonathan Birch, Henry Shevlin, Eva Jablonka, Simon Fitzpatrick, Kristin Andrews

name: Randomness in Scientific Practice
abstract: Randomness plays important roles in statistical methods, simulations, randomized trials and other experimental practices, numerical approximation, and theorem-proving. The diverse talks in this session illustrate why randomness is a rich and important area for research in philosophy of science. Speakers examine a variety of epistemological roles of different kinds of randomness from a variety of perspectives, drawing implications for methodology, epistemology, and metaphysics. Talks in this session look at roles of randomness in experiments, simulations, and statistical inference. We discuss uses deterministic randomness to solve a problem concerning experimental testing in quantum mechanics, look at whether uses of pseudorandom number generators in simulations provide evidence for pseudorandomness in nature, consider the use of random sequences as the basis of priors in Bayesian methods, and examine ways to mitigate problems due to randomness in data. Talks in this session treat randomness as a property of sequences of events, as a characteristic of sources generating events, and as a characteristic of empirical data.
subs: Randomization Posits and Fundamental Physics|On the Statistical Notion of "Population"|Randomness and Confirmation |Pseudorandomness in Simulations and Nature||
authors: Marshall Abrams, Antony Eagle, Wayne Myrvold, Barbara Osimani

name: The Rationality of Social Learning
abstract: Our symposium presents conceptual and formal results on epistemological aspects of social deliberation. It focuses on situations where experts record the opinions of others and adapt their own opinion accordingly, or where a decision maker determines her opinion on the basis of the opinions in a group of experts. The symposium consists of four papers that jointly span the space between psychological studies of deliberation and formal philosophical models of it. All papers are aimed at rationalizing deliberative practices and finding constraints on how rational social learning can obtain. The symposium has a high degree of internal coherence as it builds on a series of workshops held over the past few years within the "ColAForm" project, a research network on Collective Attitudes Formation. While focused on a specific set of themes in formal social epistemology, our symposium references a much wider research tradition in social epistemology. Insight into the rationality of social deliberation is highly relevant to studies of the social dimension of scientific inquiry, and hence to the philosophy of science, especially in its focus on science as a social process.
subs: The Role of Reliability Updating in Belief Polarization on Mixed Evidence|Extremizing: Social Learning Meets Inductive Logic|Support for Geometric Pooling|Weighted Averaging and Testimonial Updates||
authors: Jan-Willem Romeijn, Jean Baccelli, Leah Henderson, Mikaël Cozic, Denis Bonnay

name: Austere Approaches to Information and Representation in Cognitive Science
abstract:
The belief that cognition trades on representations is foundational to cognitive science; yet the theoretical underpinnings of the notions of representation and information are, paradoxically, still in flux. First, the Fodorian conception of representations as symbols in a computational system still looms large. This has pushed an important minority of cognitive scientists to skepticism about the very notion of representation. Second, there is some tension between our best contemporary theories of representation in philosophy, with their rich foundation of ancillary notions (biological function, sender-receiver architectures, causal-informational connections or asymmetries, structural correspondence, etc.); and actual appeals to representation in science, more austere, and apparently based only on the existence of correlation between neural and worldly variables. 

 

 We aim to shed light on these central issues in the philosophy of cognitive science by examining the structure of austere conceptions of representation and information. We will:

 

 i. Discuss a number of conceptions of representation and information that are widely used in cognitive science, and are typically more austere than standard philosophical ones.

 ii. Provide a clearer picture of the roles that cognitive scientists expect representation and information to play.

 iii. Explore the extent to which the above conceptions can discharge them.
subs: Conventional Meaning in the Brain?|Information Theory is a Formal Theory of Representation|Transformation over Transmission: Shifting the Focus of the Information Metaphor in Computational Neuroscience|Analog Information and Representation|Episodic Memories as Cognitive Maps|
authors: Manolo Martínez, Sarah Robins, Grace Lindsay, Charles Rathkopf, Corey Maley

name: Conceptual and Methodological Challenges in Algorithmic Fairness
abstract: Machine learning models already drive decisions in numerous sensitive domains, including social services, healthcare, financial services, and criminal justice. Importantly, however, predictive models trained on imperfect data may amplify disparities, inequalities, and biases that are encoded into that data. The emerging field of algorithmic fairness aims to orient algorithm design towards respecting ideals of fairness and justice, variously defined. This multidisciplinary symposium will bridge the technical literature on algorithmic fairness with philosophy of science by introducing philosophers of science to some of the main challenges faced by applied researchers and bringing to bear philosophical analysis on some of the contested ingredients of fair machine learning proposals. Participants come from backgrounds in philosophy, computer science, sociology, law, and the tech industry.
subs: A Non-Ideal Perspective on Algorithmic Fairness|Fairness in Data-Driven Decision-Making: A Causal Modeling Perspective|What’s Sex Got to Do with Machine Learning?|Risks of Compounding Injustices in Automated Recruiting|Racial Categories in Algorithmic Fairness: Methodological Issues and Recommendations|
authors: Sina Fazelpour, Maria De-Arteaga, Lily Hu, Emily Denton, Daniel Malinsky

name: Reconstructing Geologic Time
abstract: Reconstructing geologic time-the 4.5 billion years of Earth's history-is a vast interdisciplinary scientific project raising a tangle of conceptual and methodological issues. Scientists have organized geologic time into a hierarchical set of units known as the Geological Time Scale (GTS). The GTS sets the temporal framework for measuring the timing and tempo of all major geological, biological, and climatic processes and events in Earth's history, and hence plays a foundational role in many sciences. The aim of this symposium is to explore some of the key philosophical issues involved in the reconstruction of geologic time-a topic that has been virtually unexplored by philosophers of science. This symposium will address methods for synchronizing the imperfect clocks of geologic time (Valde), strategies for reconstructing time from the missing stratigraphic record (Bokulich), conventionality versus naturalness in delimiting the units of geologic time (Witteveen), methodological insights from shallow-time stratigraphy (Santana), and the high scientific and social costs of failing to recognize the Anthropocene as a formal unit of the GTS (Bobadilla). This symposium marks a timely and important contribution to the rapidly growing interest in the philosophy of the historical and Earth sciences.
subs: Fossil and Molecular Clocks|Learning to Measure What Isn't There: The Problem of Missing Time|Golden Spikes, Silver Bullets, and the Ma(r)king of Chronostratigraphic Boundaries|Deep Sediments; Shallow Time|What is at Stake in the Formalization of a Chronostratigraphic Unit?  A Case Study on the Anthropocene|
authors: Alisa Bokulich, Hernan Bobadilla, Carlos Santana, Joeri Witteveen, Katherine Valde

name: Scientific Speculation
abstract: Some scientists and philosophers declare speculating to be an illegitimate scientific activity, serving no purpose. Others say that it serves the purpose of initiating and developing a scientific inquiry, which could not be done without it. Of the latter, some believe that speculating is legitimate provided it is not subject to any constraints at all and is followed soon by experimental testing. Still others say that speculating in science should be encouraged and subject to no constraints, even if the speculations are never tested. And to complicate the scene even more, some say that that speculations should be encouraged and subject to constraints, but that these are empirical, local, and contextual, not universal or a priori. The aim of the proposed symposium is to focus on the purpose and legitimacy of speculating in science, and on the question of the nature of the constraints, if any, that should be imposed. Are there legitimate ways to develop as well as evaluate speculations, as speculations, without experimentally testing them? The panelists plan to examine speculations made in different sciences with the aim of dealing with these questions and others.
subs: Maxwell and Speculation |The Darwinian Tree of Life Project: Heuristic and Aesthetic Roles for Speculation|Newton on Speculation|Moving Beyond Speculation: Testing Hypotheses with Computer Simulation|Speculation in Science and Metaphysics|The Nature and Status of Speculation in the Life Sciences Around 1800
authors: Richard Richards, Peter Achinstein, Bradford Skow, Wendy Parker, Jutta Schickore, William Harper

name: Epistemic Status and Research-Strategic Role of Theories beyond the Standard Model after the Large Hadron Collider
abstract: The symposium discusses the epistemic status and research-strategic role of theories beyond the Standard Model in current particle physics. While a wide spectrum of theories beyond the Standard Model have been developed in recent decades and a lot of relevant data has been collected at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), no theory beyond the Standard Model has found empirical confirmation up to this point. This situation raises two strategic questions. How can the current status of theories beyond the Standard Model be assessed most adequately? And how should the empirical search for new physics be directed in the most effective way? Both questions are of eminent importance for the future of particle physics and both are rooted in substantial philosophical issues, such as the relation between empirical testing and theoretical analysis or the mechanism of theory confirmation. The symposium brings together expertise in physics, the philosophy of physics and the history and sociology of science to investigate these philosophical issues.
subs: Something from Nothing: ‘Non-discovery’ and Transformations in High Energy Experimental Physics at the Large Hadron Collider|Signalism vs. the Bsm Perspective: A Debate on the Role of Theory in Experimental Discovery|A Bayesian Perspective on the Search for Low Energy Supersymmetry|What Is This Thing Called Theory Space? ||
authors: Richard Dawid, Radin Dardashti, Sophie Ritson

name: Philosophical Issues in Meta-analysis
abstract: In many sciences, it is considered the "platinum standard of evidence" (Stegenga 2011). So far, the small but growing philosophical literature on meta-analysis focuses on whether meta-analysis deserves its high evidential status in the biomedical sciences (e.g. Stegenga 2011; Jukola 2015; Holman 2019). While such questions are important, there are further philosophical issues related to meta-analysis that have received almost no attention. We propose a symposium that contributes to the existing philosophical debate about meta-analysis while also extending the literature to address the questions about meta-analysis and replication, meta-analysis and the incentive structures of science, and the role of meta-analysis in other disciplines (e.g. ecology).
subs: Conventional Choices in Outcome Measures Influence Meta-Analytic Results|Replication Is for Meta-analysis|Reliability Weighting in Meta-analysis as a Response to the Replication Crisis |Just Leave It Alone? Recovery Metrics in Ecosystem Restoration||
authors: Hamed Tabatabaei Ghomi, William Berger, Samuel Fletcher, Karen Kovaka

name: Philosophy in Science: Can Philosophers of Science Contribute to Science?
abstract: Although the question of what philosophy can bring to science is an old topic, the vast majority of current philosophy of science is a meta-discourse on science, taking science as its object of study, rather than an attempt to intervene on science itself. In this symposium, we discuss a particular interventionist approach, which we call "philosophy in science (PinS)", i.e., an attempt at using philosophical tools to make a significant scientific contribution. This approach remains rare, but has been very successful in a number of cases, especially in philosophy of biology, medicine, physics, statistics, and the social sciences. Our goal is to provide a description of PinS through both a bibliometric approach and the examination of specific case studies. We also aim to explain how PinS differs from mainstream philosophy of science and partly similar approaches such as "philosophy of science in practice".
track: Doing philosophy of science - methods and tools
subs: Philosophy in Science: Definition and Boundaries|My Philosophical Interventions in Statistics|Philosophical Interventions in Science –  a Strategy and a Case Study (Parsimony)|How Evolutionary Science and Philosophy Can Collaborate to Redefine Disease||
authors: Thomas Pradeu, Deborah Mayo, Maël Lemoine, Elliott Sober, Randolph Nesse, Paul Griffiths

name: Philosophy of Science Meets AI Ethics
abstract: New artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, fueled by the rise of Big Data and related advances in machine learning, are increasingly being developed and deployed across society, including legal systems, healthcare, and public services. This has given rise to a surge of interest in ethical issues relating AI, such as algorithmic bias and opacity. While these issues have been extensively debated within applied ethics, philosophers of science have started to recognize that many of them also overlap with current debates in philosophy of science. For instance, the issue of algorithmic bias raises issues of epistemic risk and value-ladenness, while debates over the opacity and interpretability of advanced AI systems raise issues about the nature of explanation and understanding. Furthermore, they raise methodological questions about the sciences that produce these technologies, how research can be organized to produce ethical AI, and what responsibility scientists within these disciplines have to ensure this. This symposium aims to explore AI ethics through the lens of philosophy of science.
subs: Unbiased Algorithms in a Biased Society? Epistemic Risk and Value Judgments in the Design of Recidivism-Prediction Tools|Value Transparency and Value-Ladenness in Machine Learning|Inductive Risk, Understanding, and Opaque Machine Learning Models|Against Model-Based Counterfactual Explanations||
authors: Rune Nyrup, emily sullivan, Kate Vredenburgh, Justin Biddle

name: Possibility Claims in Science: Philosophy of Science Meets Modal Epistemology
abstract: In this symposium, we describe and analyze scientific practices involving possibility claims, from synthetic and evolutionary biology, climate science, and economics. These practices pose challenges to philosophy of science, including questions about the justification of possibility claims, the representation of possibilities through models, the distinction of genuine from non-genuine possibilities, and what the relevant concept(s) of 'possibility' is in a given field. We advance understanding of these problems by analyzing the possibility claims and the associated practices with tools and arguments from modal epistemology. Although modal epistemology has only addressed scientific possibility claims to a rather limited extent, it has recently undergone an "empirical turn", investigating justification strategies for modal claims based on empirical evidence – thus making it amenable to issues in the philosophy of science. The resources from modal epistemology that we are employing include conceptual distinctions, new perspectives, and novel justificatory strategies. With this approach, the symposium aims to achieve three goals. First, it aims to raise awareness of interesting philosophical issues relating to scientific practices involving possibility claims. Second, it advances the philosophical analysis of these issues. Finally, it showcases how drawing on modal epistemology can help philosophy of science in this matter.
subs: The (Un)Easily Possible Synthetic Biology?|Spaces of the Biologically Possible|Mapping Possibilities in Climate Science|Representing Possible Targets?||
authors: Till Grüne-Yanoff, Philippe Verreault-Julien, Ylwa Sjölin Wirling, Rami Koskinen, Tarja Knuuttila

name: Why Trust Science?
abstract:
The authority of science continues to face serious challenges along a variety of different dimensions. Distrust of science is on the rise in the educated public. The "replication crisis" has fundamentally shaken researchers' sense of trust in one another's results. And the most straightforward epistemic justification for science's cognitive authority rests upon the increasingly fragile thesis of scientific realism. 

Our symposium presents new research on the historical, conceptual, and broader social aspects of the problem of trusting science, bringing together philosophers working at the frontier of current research. By looking at problems associated with the authority of science in a variety of contexts, the symposium promises to stimulate fruitful discussion, collaboration, and thought for future work.
subs: Why Trust Science?|Trust Issues|Forms of Trust in Science|Trust of Science as a Public Collective Good||
authors: Chris Haufe, Naomi Oreskes, Matthew Slater, Heidi Grasswick

name: Non-Metaphysical Resolutions of the Hole Dilemma
abstract: The past five years have seen a resurgence of interest in Einstein's infamous `hole argument', which was initially offered by Einstein in 1913 as an argument against what he called `general covariance'; and which was famously rehabilitated by Earman, Norton, and Stachel in the 1980s as an argument against a metaphysical doctrine that Earman and Norton called `manifold substantivalism'. Early philosophical reactions to the Earman-Norton version of the argument focused on articulating and defending versions of substantivalism that could avoid the dire conclusions of the hole argument. The new literature, by contrast, which has included contributions from mathematicians, physicists, and philosophers, has focused on what might be called \emph{non-metaphysical} resolutions of the dilemma posed by the argument. The purpose of this symposium is to bring together philosophers and physicists who have worked on different aspects of this new literature, to explore how the different strands---which have developed largely independently---relate to and may inform one another.
track: Philosophy of Physics - space and time
subs: Mathematics, Metaphysics, and the Hole Argument: Then and Now|Patching up the Representation of Spacetime in General Relativity|Metaphysical Considerations after Resolving the Hole Dilemma without Metaphysics|Permutations and Charts: Is the Hole Argument a Puzzle about Reference?||
authors: Robert Rynasiewicz, James Weatherall, Francesca Vidotto, James Ladyman, Clara Bradley

name: Big Data and Climate Science
abstract: Data continues to get bigger, and if popular accounts are to be believed, analysis of these big data will revolutionize ordinary life in the developed world. While the impact of big data is already being felt in the commerce and marketing sectors, its novelty, and potential contribution to scientific research, is still up for debate. This symposium asks what makes data big, and how should we understand reasoning with big data in light of differences across scientific disciplines. To answer this question, this symposium considers the case of climate science. The five talks in this symposium address crucial questions: What makes big data big in any given context, and is big data unique to the contemporary scientific moment? Is the kind of data-centric reasoning highlighted by philosophers in disciplines like genetics and biology contiguous with the use of big data in climate science? Can traditional representational conceptions of data advanced by philosophers account for the malleability of big data? By answering these questions, this symposium advances philosophic understanding of the ways big data techniques may advance (or hinder) patterns of scientific reasoning and justification.
subs: Why Climate Data Is Big|A Defense of the Representational Account of Data|The Ontology of Big Data in Climate Science|||
authors: Seth McGinnis, Stuart Gluck, Greg Lusk

name: Precision Medicine as Promissory Science: The Epistemology and Ethics of a “Health Care Revolution”
abstract: Precision medicine is promised to dramatically transform medicine and health care through data-intensive strategies that enable individualized treatments and disease prevention. Successful examples of targeted treatments in the context of certain cancers and rare diseases are often taken to illustrate the revolutionary potential of precision medicine in other contexts. This symposium critically examines the assumptions underlying this expectation. Precision medicine is often promoted as a unified solution to current challenges in health care without recognition of the complexities of the various contexts of implementation. One example is the ideal of "patient empowerment" in primary care, where risk information is envisioned to enable patients to take control over future health outcomes. This vision, however, presupposes quite significant epistemic assumptions, and implies a shift in the organization of health care systems. This includes changes in the relationship between doctors and patients, as well as in their respective roles and responsibilities. The symposium offers an overview of how precision medicine has developed as a promissory science, recently distancing itself from "personalized medicine", and calls for a calibration of expectations according to existing evidence of health benefits.
subs: Scoping Precision Medicine|Precision Medicine and the Ideal of Patient Empowerment|Impact of Precision Medicine on Physician-Patient Relationships|Personalized Medicine Wasn't Personal; Precision Medicine Isn't Precise ||
authors: Jim Tabery, Sara Green, Paul Appelbaum, Kathryn Tabb

name: Science and Justice
abstract: Because of the centrality of science in contemporary society and its potent ability to shape discourses, decisions, and resource distribution, philosophers of science need to attend to issues of justice, particularly distributive, social, and inter-generational justice, in the practice and aims of science. Whether we adopt a prospective approach and offer recommendations for what science and scientists ought to be doing, or a stance focused on the description of actual scientific practices and the identification of existing inequalities, issues of justice need to move from the periphery to the center in contemporary philosophy of science. This symposium will address this epistemic need, and will aim to jumpstart a more robust conversation about the relationship between science and justice. Questions to be addressed include: Can justice be the, or an, aim of science? How do scientists deal with injustices in specific contexts? How can scientists work to ensure science does not contribute to injustice? And what does a science for the purpose of justice look like? The four talks tackle these questions and canvas possible answers to them, drawing from a plurality of social-political theories- including both the liberal tradition and critical theory-regarding what counts as an injustice in science.
subs: Institutions, Forethought, and Scientists’ Responsibility for Social Justice|Critical Theory for Science|The Limits of Democratizing Science:  When Scientists Should Ignore the Public|Epistemic severing and epistemic trademarking. Two garden varieties of epistemic injustice in science||
authors: Michela Massimi, Dan Hicks, Heather Douglas, Andrew Schroeder

name: The Emergence of Spacetime in Quantum Gravity Big Bang Models
abstract:
In general relativity, spacetime comes to an `end' at the big bang (or crunch). But from the point of view of quantum gravity (QG) the singularity represents an era in which a more fundamental description must be given, while at later times the classical spacetime description is derived. The purpose of this symposium is to review some current physical knowledge (and hypotheses) of the nature of the big bang in QG, and what philosophical lessons about the nature of space and time may be drawn. Since QG promises to replace existing spacetime concepts with more fundamental ones, these lessons may be momentous; since the big bang is precisely a place at which the classical picture gives way to the quantum, it is a very fruitful context in which these questions are explored.

Physicists and philosophers will give talks covering big bang models in central approaches to QG and some of the philosophical questions and lessons to which they give rise, and reflect on the limitations of such lessons given our as yet limited understanding of QG. This symposium will provide a state-of-the-art presentation of these matters which will hopefully encourage philosophers to engage in this important work.
track: Philosophy of Physics - space and time
subs: Can Time Emerge?|Cosmology as Quantum Gravity Hydrodynamics, Spacetime Emergence and the Fate of Cosmological Singularities: Overview and Conceptual Implications|Singularity Resolution: The Case of the Vanishing Wavefunction|Dynamical Laws at the Big Bang||
authors: Niranjana Warrier, Christian Wüthrich, Nick Huggett, Ted Jacobson, Daniele Oriti

name: The Revival of Instrumentalism
abstract: There has been a recent resurgence of interest in strong forms of scientific anti-realism, as opposed to the selective (or moderate) forms of scientific realism developed in recent decades. This is reflected, for example, by the recent publication of two monographs written by prospective participants – _Resisting Scientific Realism_ by K. Brad Wray, and _The Instrument of Science: Scientific Anti-Realism Revitalised_ by Darrell P. Rowbottom – and in the ongoing influence of the work of P. Kyle Stanford. This symposium will further explore and evaluate the prospects of such forms of instrumentalism, and reassess the state of the realism debate as a result.
subs: Is There a Positive Argument for Instrumentalism?|An Instrumentalist Account of Scientific Understanding|Semantic Instrumentalism Revived: An Invitation to Scientific Realists|Lessons from the Strawman Instrumentalist||
authors: Darrell Rowbottom, Julian Reiss, Stathis Psillos, K Brad Wray

name: What Is Socially Responsible Science?
abstract: Philosophers of science, particularly those working on science and values, often talk about the need for science to be socially responsible. It is however not always clear what this means. For example, does socially responsible science require individual, group norms, or both? Does it involve only epistemic responsibilities or it includes moral constraints? Whose needs does socially responsible science address? Is it the needs of the general public, stakeholders affected by the research, or groups with certain characteristics (e.g., marginalized, least well off)? What are the specific responsibilities scientists are accountable for in order for science so be socially responsible? Are they accountable for the research problems addressed, the methodologies employed, the resulting products, or some combination of these? What mechanisms (e.g., public engagement?) might be necessary for, or can facilitate, socially responsible science? This symposium brings together a diverse group of philosophers of science to address these questions.
subs: Socially Responsible Science: Mapping the Terrain|Socially Responsible Science as Accountable Science|How to Identify Socially Responsible Research Endeavors?|Representation Without Reification||
authors: Inmaculada De Melo-Martin, Joyce C. Havstad, Martin Carrier, Kristen Intemannq, Haixin Dang

name: Concepts as Epistemic Tools: A Comparative Approach
abstract: This symposium gathers together four papers investigating (a) the various epistemic functions served by scientific concepts, (b) the often complicated structures that concepts take on in order to serve these functions, and (c) the dynamics of conceptual change in the course of inquiry. Each paper focuses on a particular case study, using this as a springboard to think more generally about the above issues. The four concepts considered are: 'slow infection', 'Wilsonian renormalization', 'homology', and 'species'. The papers share an emphasis on considering epistemic functions beyond mere reference; in this way, they contribute to an expanded view of the functions of scientific language.
subs: How “Slow Infections” (Slowly) Paved the Way to “Prions"|Renormalization as a Phantom Concept|‘Species’ Without Species: A Patchwork Approach to Thinking About ‘Species’ Concepts|Essentially Dynamic Concepts and the Case of Homology||
authors: Aaron Novick, Zachary Shifrel, Corinne Bloch-Mullins, Amesh Adalja, Devin Gouvêa

name: Current Debates on Statistical Modeling and Inference
abstract: Statistical methods play an essential role in an extremely wide range of human reasoning. From theorizing in the physical and social sciences to determining evidential standards in legal contexts, statistical methods are ubiquitous, and so are questions about their adequate application. As tools for making inferences that go beyond a given set of data, they are inherently a means of inductive, or ampliative reasoning, and so it is unsurprising that philosophers have used statistical frameworks to further our understanding of these topics. Yet statistical methods are undergoing considerable debate with important implications for standards of research across social and biological science. In the last decade many published results in the medical and social sciences have been found not to replicate. This has sparked debates about the very nature of statistical inference and modeling. Combining perspectives from philosophy, statistics, psychology, and economics, our symposium focuses on these recent debates. It will be a topical session building on Deborah Mayo's Statistical Inference as Severe Testing: How to Get Beyond the Statistics Wars (CUP, 2018), and a 2019 Summer Seminar on Philosophy of Statistics co-directed by D. Mayo and A. Spanos, in which all presenters of our proposed session participated (https://summerseminarphilstat.com/).
subs: Self-Correction and Statistical Misspecification|Measuring Severity in Statistical Inference|Psychometric Models: Statistics and Interpretation|Is Algorithmic Fairness Possible? |Statistical Modeling, Mis-specification Testing, and Exploration |
authors: Ruobin Gong, Marcello Di Bello, Elay Shech, Riet van Bork, Jan-Willem Romeijn, Aris Spanos, Mike Tamir

name: Neural Networks as Models of the Human Mind
abstract:
Since its birth, cognitive science has taken inspiration from computer science, using state-of-art technologies as models for how the human mind works. Today, cognitive scientists are beginning to grapple with Deep Neural Nets, perhaps the most impressive and difficult to understand advances in computing thus far. The striking success of DNNs suggests that perhaps there are deep similarities between them and the human mind. However, DNNs display bizarre behaviors and their inner workings are (allegedly) inscrutable, which would seem to undermine their value as a model of the mind. 

In this symposium, we will examine the status of machine learning models of cognition. First, supposing that the analogy is a probative one, we suggest that it sheds light on traditional philosophical controversies about concepts. Second, we will critically examine the evidence from adversarial examples that has been taken undermine the similarity between human and machine concepts. Lastly, we will discuss how tools used to investigate human minds can break open the "black box" of DNNs.

This investigation will introduce philosophers of science to cutting edge work in machine learning and cognitive science, and provide a fascinating case study of the use of model systems in science.
subs: Taking a Machine’s Perspective|Machine Learning and Conceptual Complexity|Functional Intelligibility and Neural Network Models of the Brain|Interpreting Deep Learning's Susceptibility to Adversarial Examples|Learning Incommensurate Concepts |
authors: Hayley Clatterbuck, Cameron Buckner, Jens Kipper, Chaz Firestone, Rosa Cao

name: The Fundamental Physical Constants: Knowledge and Measurement
abstract: High-precision measurements of the fundamental physical constants show promise as a new source of insights regarding the nature of scientific knowledge. The consistent determination of dozens of fundamental constants provides the most stringent tests of current physical theories. Despite the remarkable success of these measurements, philosophers have not yet focused sufficient attention on the reasons for this success and the nature of the knowledge that emerges out of it. The aim of this symposium is to explore the nature of this knowledge by bringing together the perspectives of philosophy of physics, the philosophy of scientific methodology, and the philosophy of measurement. Among other topics, the symposium will examine the nature of scientific evidence emerging from precision measurement of physical constants in quantum electrodynamics and cosmology; provide new insights into the nature of scientific units and their connection to physical constants; and show how the precision measurement of physical constants can provide strategies for resolving methodological conundrums.
subs: Disrupting Zanzibars: The Epistemic Function of High Precision Divergence|The Role of Fundamental Constants in the International System of Units (SI)|The Interlinking Role of the Fine Structure Constant|Trouble with Hubble: Status of Big Bang Models|Fundamental Constants and Quantum Field Theory|
authors: Teru Miyake, Alistair Isaac, Chris Smeenk, Adam Koberinski, Susan Sterrett

name: The Sciences of Sexual Desire
abstract: The sciences of sexual desire range from anthropology to zoology, and include genetics, immunology, physiology, sociology, statistics, economics, psychology, psychiatry, and evolutionary biology. There are numerous philosophical issues pertaining to the scientific study of sexual desire, including conceptual, methodological, ontological, moral, and political questions. This symposium will ask: is low sexual desire a genuine disease? What is a 'sexuality', and how many in fact are there? How should we interpret the empirical evidence pertaining to alleged sex-differences in sexual desire? Should some topics of research about our sexual desires be prohibited on normative grounds? To generate a robust discussion about these important and challenging questions and topics, our symposium includes a professionally and demographically diverse range of participants.
subs: Don’t Publish, So That We Don’t Perish: the Case For and Against the Use of Neural Networks to Detect Sexual Orientation.  |Science in the Service of Cultural Norms - the Pathologization of Female Desire|Sex Differences in Sexual Desire|Sexuality and Genderality:  On Personal and Conjoined Embodiment|Commentator|
authors: Katarzyna Grunt-Mejer, Nicole Vincent, Jacob Stegenga, John Dupre, Andreas De Block, Erin Nash

name: Fast and Furious: Climate Change in the Chesapeake Bay, What We Know and How We Know It
abstract:
Open to the public and free of charge.

The Public Forum will feature a discussion about climate change and the Chesapeake Bay between philosophers and historians of science and the Assistant Administrator for NOAA Oceanic and Atmospheric Research, as well as the public. The PSA Public Forum invites interested people to join a conversation about what led to scientific predictions of changes in the Chesapeake Bay and how and why they got it so right? What goes into modeling the complex factors that have led to the rise of sea level, the warming water, and extreme weather that impact the wildlife on land and the fish and shellfish in the water? The event will feature three panelists (a philosopher, a historian, and a scientist) and a moderator, who is also a philosopher. Each panelist will make brief remarks highlighting philosophical issues related to how science works, why it succeeded in predicting changes in the Chesapeake Bay, and how it avoided mistakes that would have led to wrong projections. This will be followed by an open discussion between the three panelists facilitated by the moderator, and then the moderator will invite questions from the audience. The discussion is intended to be accessible to all those interested.

Panelists

  • Naomi Oreskes (Professor of the History of Science and Affiliated Professor of Earth and Planetary Sciences, Harvard University)

    A world-renowned geologist, historian and public speaker, she is a leading voice on the role of science in society and the reality of anthropogenic climate change. 

    Oreskes is author or co-author of over 200 scholarly and popular books, articles, and opinion pieces, including Merchants of Doubt (Bloomsbury, 2010), The Collapse of Western Civilization (Columbia University Press, 2014), Discerning Experts (University Chicago Press, 2019), Why Trust Science? (Princeton University Press, 2019), and Science on a Mission: American Oceanography from the Cold War to Climate Change (University of Chicago Press, forthcoming). Merchants of Doubt, co-authored with Erik Conway, was the subject of a documentary film of the same name produced by participant Media and distributed by SONY Pictures Classics, and has been translated into eight languages.

    Oreskes wrote the Introduction to the Melville House edition of the Papal Encyclical on Climate Change and Inequality, Laudato Si, and her opinion pieces on climate change have appeared in leading newspapers around the globe, including The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times, the Times (London), and Frankfurter Allegemeine. Her awards and prizes include the 2016 Stephen Schneider Award for outstanding Climate Science Communication, the 2015 Public Service Award of the Geological Society of America, the 2015 Herbert Feis Prize of the American Historical Association for her contributions to public history, the 2014 American Geophysical Union Presidential Citation for Science and Society. She is a fellow of the American Geophysical Union, the Geological Society of America, and the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

    In 2018 she was named a Guggenheim Fellow for a new book project with Erik Conway, "The Magic of the Marketplace: The True History of a False Idea," which will be published by Bloomsbury Press.

  • Wendy Parker (Professor of Philosophy, Virginia Tech)

    Wendy Parker's research focuses on the methodology and epistemology of contemporary science – especially questions related to modelling, evidence, explanation and values – with a particular focus on climate science and meteorology. Her papers have been published in a range of philosophical and scientific journals, including Philosophy of Science, the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society, Climatic Change and Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society. Since 2017, she has been Co-Editor-in-Chief of the British Journal for the Philosophy of Science. Wendy is also very interested in the use of science in policymaking. Upon finishing her PhD, she spent a year as the American Meteorological Society / University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (AMS/UCAR) Congressional Science Fellow in the U.S. Senate. She is currently a contributing author to the 6th Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

  • Craig McLean (Acting Chief Science and Assistant Administrator, Oceanic and Atmospheric Research, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration). 

    Craig McLean is serving as the Acting Chief Scientist of NOAA providing direction for science and technology priorities as well as the Assistant Administrator for NOAA Oceanic and Atmospheric Research. He is responsible for overseeing, directing and implementing NOAA's research enterprise including a network of research laboratories and the execution of NOAA programs including the Climate Program, Weather Research, National Sea Grant, and Ocean Exploration, to name a few. Among a number of formal international engagements in science and technology, Mr. McLean serves as the U.S. Representative to the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission (IOC), and as the U.S. Representative for the U.S.-European Union-Canada Galway Statement on Atlantic Ocean Cooperation.

    Mr. McLean has previously served throughout NOAA, in the National Marine Fisheries Service, National Ocean Service, NOAA's General Counsel, and was the founding Director of NOAA's Ocean Exploration program. He served in uniform for nearly 25 years in NOAA's Commissioned Corps, retiring at the rank of Captain. Mr. McLean is a Fellow of the Explorers Club and of the Marine Technology Society, and a past-president and former chairman of the Sea-Space Symposium.

Moderator

  • Michael Weisberg (Professor and Chair of Philosophy at the University of Pennsylvania and Perry World House's Inaugural Faculty Fellow)

    Michael Weisberg serves as the Editor-in-Chief of Biology and Philosophy and co-director of the Penn Laboratory for Understanding Science and the Galápagos Education and Research Alliance. His research focuses on methodological issues arising in the life and social sciences, especially the ways that highly idealized models and simulations can be used to understand complex systems. He also works on climate adaptation issues that sit at the interface of physical, biological, and social systems. Dr. Weisberg's research group has recently completed the most comprehensive study to date of North Americans' attitudes about and knowledge of evolutionary biology, and is working with experimental documentary filmmaking techniques to help address common misconceptions. He regularly discusses his findings with academic audiences, policy makers, and the public including audiences at the Penn Lightbulb Café, BBC's "Up All Night," the AAAS, the National Academy of Sciences, and with park officials, naturalist guides, and tourists in the Galápagos.

name: President’s Plenary: A PSA Forum on Climate Change Action
abstract:
How can the PSA and its members best respond to the climate crisis?

The PSA invites our members to join in the discussion and recommend concrete strategies for implementing the widely endorsed Philosophy for Sustainability Guidelines. Share your wisdom and experience about how we can make a difference as philosophers of science, individually and collectively. Moderated by Alison Wylie, PSA President (2019-2020) and the Kerry McKenzie (Chair, PSA Climate Change Task Force).

Speakers

  • Kyle Whyte
  • Andrew Light
  • Michael Weisberg
  • Karen Kovaka
