name: AAPT-PSA Teaching Hub
abstract:
Abstract: The American Association of Philosophy Teachers (AAPT) is an association that focuses on the advancement of the art of teaching philosophy. Recently, the AAPT has partnered with other philosophical associations to run "Teaching Hubs" at those conferences. Teaching Hubs aim to bring active, student-centered teaching discussions and resources to the wider audience of philosophy instructors. This AAPT-PSA Teaching Hub seeks to bring AAPT-style pedagogy to the problems facing the teaching of philosophy of science.

The AAPT-PSA Teaching Hub is a series of interactive workshops and conversations designed specifically for philosophers of science and created to celebrate teaching within the context of the PSA biannual meetings. Organized by the American Association of Philosophy Teachers, the Teaching Hub aims to offer a range of high quality and inclusive development opportunities that address the teaching of philosophy of science at all levels, pre-college though graduate school. This session first provides a brief introduction to AAPT Teaching Hubs, followed by two workshop sessions: (1) The Thinking Science project, which aims to bring philosophical questioning to science education for schoolchildren. This extension of the project covers various topics involving AI, big data and robotics. (2) "Robust Classrooms: Redesigning Science Learning" details an approach to teaching that scientific modeling necessarily involves choices and the integration of visual technology. The session leaders have implemented this teaching strategy through the modeling of COVID-19. Additionally, the session leaders will demonstrate one way to effectively integrate visual technology into a group project about modeling.
subs: Introduction to the AAPT-PSA Teaching Hub|Thinking Science: Information Technology and People|Robust Classrooms: Redesigning Science Learning Environments|||
authors: Melissa Jacquart, Vadim Keyser, Hannah Howland, Ellen Hart

name: Committee for Integrated HPS
abstract:
Case Studies: Putting the H back in HPS


One of the perennial themes in the field of "integrated HPS" is the question about the nature and role of case studies for historical and philosophical analyses of science. What philosophical lessons, if any, can we draw from examining specific historical events and processes? 

In the decades after the historical turn of philosophy of science in the wake of Lakatos, Kuhn, Laudan, and others, HPS was associated with the notion that philosophical concepts and ideas should be tested against the historical record. Case studies were expected to probe the historical adequacy, and thus the relevance to science, of philosophical concepts and theories about science. 

During the last decade or so, however, the notion that philosophical concepts and theories could be empirically tested has been cast into doubt. What could it mean to "test" philosophical concepts against the historical record? Is it really a "test" of a philosophical concept if we find an episode that fits with that concept? How can we prevent cherry-picking our cases? Should we study cases that could potentially refute our philosophical theories? What could the terms "fit" or "refute" even mean in this context? What can we learn from a single case study, or even a few case studies, about science tout court? And what are "case studies" anyway? 

Yet, despite all these misgivings regarding the idea that we should test philosophy of science with cases, investigating actual scientific episodes remains a crucial part of HPS. In their attempts to find more appropriate characterizations of the nature and role of historical case studies for philosophy of science, scholars within the field, including Hasok Chang (2012) and Katherina Kinzel (2015), among others, have moved the discussion beyond the simple notion of "testing philosophy with cases". This session further examines the nature of case studies and their role for philosophical inquiry through illustration and systematic analysis. Three of the papers present historical episodes drawn from different fields of inquiry and different historical periods: the construction of a cervimeter to measure cervical dilation (Jackson); the application of Bohr's atomic model to helium (Kaveh); and research on scorpion suicide (Arnet). Each presenter utilizes the case study to consider broader philosophical issues: the concept of units of measurement (Jackson); predictive success (Kaveh); and continuity and change in scientific knowledge production (Arnet); to reflect on the question of how the historical material could help clarify the philosophical issues at stake. 

The three concrete analyses are framed by a paper (Bolinska & Martin) and a commentary (Chang) which discuss the structure and functions of historical case studies more abstractly. Together, the five contributions to this session provide rich opportunities to think through questions such as: What are the distinctive features of philosophically informed case studies of past science? How strictly should our case studies adhere to the standards of professional history of science? What makes particular historical episodes good, fruitful, and suitable for philosophical analysis? What kinds of philosophical insights can be gained by engaging with historical cases, and might the work with cases perhaps constrain or limit philosophical analyses in certain ways? 


Kinzel, K., Narrative and evidence. How can case studies from the history of science support claims in the philosophy of science?, History and Philosophy of Science 49 (2015): 48-57.


Chang, H. Beyond case-studies: History as philosophy, in: S. Mauskopf, T. Schmaltz (eds.), Integrating History and Philosophy of Science (Springer, 2012): 109-124.
subs: What Is a Canonical Case?|Constructing Centimeters: Emanuel Friedman’s Cervimeter and the Dilatation-Time Curve|What Helium Teaches Us About the Poverty of Referential Relations|Scorpion suicide and the use of case studies for diachronic analysis||
authors: Shahin Kaveh, Agnes Bolinska, Evan Arnet, Joseph Martin, Rebecca Jackson

name: International Network for Economic Method (INEM)
abstract:
Modality and How-Possibly Explanations in Economics


Short summary (180)

There is a growing interest concerning the modal features of modelling across the sciences, with

economics being no exception. Economic modelling practices do not fit the procrustean bed of

full how-actually explanations and the demanding criteria on models that come with it. Instead of

dismissing these practices as epistemically inert, more effort must be invested in investigating

the role they play in establishing modal claims and providing how-possibly explanations.

However, we still have a limited understanding of how how-possibly explanations are formed

and used in practice and of their relationship with how-actually explanations. We also lack


methodological criteria that would help us to assess the epistemic and heuristic value of how-

possibly explanations.


This session aims to make three chief contributions. First, we show that the practice of

establishing modal claims is well entrenched in the practice of economists, even those with an

eye on policy. Second, we illuminate how how-possibly explanations relate to economic

modelling practices and how they are used to acquire how-actually explanations of phenomena

of interest. Third, we provide methodological resources to appraise how-possibly explanations in

economics.


Topic description (991)

How we can learn about the world with highly idealized models has been a vexing philosophical

issue. These models often do not faithfully describe the world as it is, yet it also seems they are

not epistemically vacuous. Philosophers have started to draw attention to the modal features of

scientific modelling (e.g. Betz 2015; Bokulich 2014; Knuuttila and Koskinen 2020; Massimi

2019; Rice 2016; Shech and Gelfert 2019; Weisberg 2013). According to that growing body of

literature, scientists sometimes seek to establish possibility claims. For instance, biologists

synthesize potential organisms (Elowitz and Lim 2010) and physicists model impossible

perpetual motion machines (Feynman, Leighton, and Sands 2010) to further our understanding of

the world. They pursue the epistemic goals of science by inquiring into the possible and

impossible.

We observe a similar interest concerning economic models. They are sometimes said to describe

credible worlds (Sugden 2000, 2009), establish possibility claims to rebut impossibility ones

(Grüne-Yanoff 2009), or provide how-possibly explanations (Aydinonat 2007, 2008; Ylikoski

and Aydinonat 2014). All this draws attention to the modal features of economic modelling

(Hausman 1984; Rappaport 1986, 1989, 1998): economics pursues not only its aims by

investigating what is actual, but also what is possible. Moreover, while some philosophers of

economics are pessimistic about the capacities of economic models to accurately represent the

actual world and explain (Alexandrova and Northcott 2013), others have suggested that they

might fare better as representations of genuine possibilities (Grüne-Yanoff 2013; Verreault-

Julien 2017; Ylikoski and Aydinonat 2014), thus offering an alternative and nuanced vindication

of current economic modelling practices.


The methodology of economics needs this nuance. Prediction and explanation are commonly

considered as the most important goals of economic modelling. Yet, typical accounts of

economic modelling that rely on representational adequacy and robustness as criteria for success

suggest that most economic models fail to achieve these goals (Aydinonat and Köksal 2019). It is

true that economic models often do not meet the decomposability assumptions needed for

minimalist accounts of idealization (Cartwright 2009; Grüne-Yanoff 2011) and that most of them

are not robust to many kinds of de-idealizations (Knuuttila and Morgan 2019). Thus, they are

unlikely candidates for providing good predictions or explanations. But it does not follow from

this that most economic modelling is deficient. The reason is that the dominant accounts of

economic modelling do not do much justice to practice of economic modelling and particularly

to its modal features. Before dismissing these practices as epistemically inert, one must invest

more effort in investigating the role models play in establishing modal claims and providing

how-possibly explanations.

However, we currently have a limited understanding of modal modelling. No systematic survey

of modal modelling practices in economics exists, and few proposals have been offered how to

categorize and systematize these practices. Nor are there clear analyses of the epistemic

contributions of economic modal modelling. Do they consist in how-possibly explanations that

have epistemic value in their own right, or do they indirectly contribute to how-actually

explanations, and only through that acquire value? Furthermore, we also lack methodological

criteria for assessing the quality of specific how-possibly explanations.

This session focusses on those modelling practices that relate to how-possibly explanations. It

consists of three papers that examine distinct features of how-possibly explanations in

economics. Each paper documents some specific modal modelling practices in economics,

ranging from central bank modelling through trade theory to modelling cooperation. Each paper

then analyses how these practices make a substantial epistemic contribution, and concludes by

identifying criteria for assessing the quality of these modal modelling practices.

The first paper focusses on models considered potential candidates for providing causal

explanations, as one finds them, e.g., in central bank multi-model platforms. When considered on

their own, these models merely provide 'thin' how-possibly explanations of little epistemic

value. Yet, in practice, these models are crucial for acquiring how-actually explanations. The

paper illustrates such practices by showing how the Bank of England integrates multiple how-

possibly models in its COMPASS platform, aiming at how-actually explanation of real-world 

phenomena, and it investigates the success conditions of such how-actually explanations in terms

of how well they facilitate reasoning about reliable intervention.

The second paper emphasizes that economists often make use of multiple models along with

other sources of information in their quest for explaining actual phenomena. Therefore,

individual models rarely function as explanantia. Rather, economists typically use a set of

models (each of them highly idealized) to construct a 'menu' of possible explanations,

viz. explanations whose truth isn't yet established. When doing so, they rely on a diversity of

models and sources of evidence. Determining the actual explanation is then a matter of

eliminating the possible candidate explanations and establishing the truth of the relevant

explanantia.

The third paper argues that the practice of providing 'mere' how-possibly explanations does not

entitle economists to formulate any just-so story they wish. It proposes a conceptual framework

that allows assessing 'good' from 'bad' how-possibly explanations. This conceptual framework

relies on two key distinctions: the first between how-actually and how-possibly explanations, the

second between epistemic and objective how-possibly explanations. It argues that both of these

latter categories afford their own epistemically relevant results, and both have the conceptual

resources to distinguish between good and bad models. The paper illustrates these arguments

with examples from trade theory, economic geography, and social cooperation.

With these three presentations, the session aims to further our understanding of how-possibly

explanations and modal modelling in economics. In particular, we pursue three goals. First, we

show that the practice of establishing modal claims is well entrenched in the modelling strategies

of economists, even those with an eye on policy. Second, we illuminate how how-possibly

explanations make substantial epistemic contributions, either by establishing relevant free-

standing modal claims or by facilitating, in conjunction with other sources of information, the

development of how-actually explanations of phenomena of interest. Third, we provide

methodological guidelines for assessing the quality of how-possibly explanations, thus showing

that they are distinct from methodologically naive just-so stories.
subs: The Needle in the Haystack: Finding the Actual Amongst the Possible|Economic Models and Possible Explanation|How-Possibly Explanations in Economics: Anything Goes?|||
authors: Till Grüne-Yanoff, Jennifer Jhun, N. Emrah Aydinonat

name: Minorities and Philosophy (MAP)
abstract:
Topic: Race and Racial Justice


MAP's mission is to address structural injustices in academic philosophy and to remove

barriers that impede participation in academic philosophy for members of marginalized groups. In

this symposium, we are proud to present the work of three early-career philosophers on the

intersection of race, racial justice, and scientific practices. Speakers will reveal the critical roles that

race and racial justice play in biology, medicine, and environmental science, from the perspectives of

metaphysics, epistemology, and ethics. Ian Peebles poses the following question: when is it morally

permissible to use a biological racial classification (BRC) in medicine in such a way that aligns with

racial justice? Using a virtue ethics framework, Peebles introduces three constraints for the

permissible use of BRC in medicine, while withholding any metaphysical commitment to the reality

of these classifications. Celso Neto will present arguments from inductive risk to challenge a version

of biological race realism. Because socio-political values inevitably influence claims about kinds,

Neto contends, potentially harmful consequences of biological race realism must be addressed by

proponents of this view. Finally, Jesi Taylor Cruz draws our attention to the high concentration of

pollutants and biohazards in U.S. carceral environments such as jails, prisons, and detention centers.

Using the New York City carceral archipelago as a case study, Cruz will examine the complex

relationships among climate science, public health, and chronic disenfranchisement to shed light on

the role of environmental racism in the project of state-building.
subs: To race or not to race: when (if ever) is it morally permissible to use a biological racial  classification in medicine?|The Metaphysics of Race meets Inductive Risk: Issues for the New Deflationary Biological  Race Realism|Carceral Wastelands: On Waste Inequity and Mass Incarceration in the US|||
authors: Celso Neto, Ian Peebles, Jesi Cruz

name: Society for Philosophy of Technology (SPT)
abstract:
Work in the field of philosophy of technology overlaps with the philosophy science upon multiple points of study. Perhaps the most straightforward of these is the topic of scientific instrumentation. Philosophers of technology study laboratory instrumentation through a variety of perspectives, approaching the epistemological, material, practical, and embodied aspects of these devices along multiple trajectories. Participants in our panel address the concrete details of these devices-from neuroscientific brain stimulation, to Landsat images of Earth, to Hubble images of Mars-and their roles in scientific investigation. Scholars in this particular panel bring insights from both the phenomenological and American pragmatic schools of thought.

The panel also serves as a celebration of recent books published in the book series "Postphenomenology and the Philosophy of Technology." The presenters on this panel are authors or editors of books that are forthcoming or have been published over the past year. They include Bas de Boer's monograph How Scientific Instruments Speak: Postphenomenology and Technological Mediations in Neuroscientific Practice, Samantha J. Fried and Robert Rosenberger's collection Postphenomenology and Imaging: How to Read Technology, and Andrew Wells Garnar and Ashley Shew's Feedback Loops: Pragmatism about Science and Technology, a festschrift on the work of Joe Pitt.
subs: Philosophy of Technology as a Hyperspace Transmogrifier|How Scientific Instruments Speak: Technological Mediations in Neuroscientific Practice|On the Multistability of Images in Science:   Examples from Neurobiological and Planetary Imaging |||
authors: Ashley Shew, Andrew Garnar, Bas de Boer, Samantha Fried, Robert Rosenberger

name: Society for Philosophy and Psychology (SPP)
abstract:
Philosophical and Psychological Perspectives on Explanation


This symposium will feature five projects at the intersection of philosophy and psychology

exploring the structure and content of explanation. The contributors will address philosophical

questions about how explanations are constructed and interpreted in light of psychological

findings about scientific cognition. The symposium will consist of five 15-minute talks, with

three minutes following each talk for questions.


Sara Aronowitz will begin the symposium with a discussion of structural constraints on

explanation, arguing that satisfying explanations contain not just abstract, semantic structure but

also experiential, temporal structure. Daniel Wilkenfeld, Richard Samuels, and James Fritz will

then explore the structure of a particular kind of explanation-mathematical explanation-by

probing psychological attitudes about the truth of mathematical statements and the existence of

mathematical entities. Next, Elizabeth Bonawitz will present an interdisciplinary model of

scientific reasoning, demonstrating how explanatory activities are constrained by cognitive

engagement, via questions and thought experiments, as well as cognitive emotions, like

uncertainty and surprise. David Danks will then present a model of theory discovery, arguing

that cognitive science provides a precedent for at least two rational (logic-based) pathways of

discovery: automated discovery via machine learning and deliberative discovery via theory-

based inference. Andrew Shtulman will conclude the symposium by exploring the question of

what happens to folk explanations of natural phenomena when we acquire scientific explanations

of the same phenomena and whether we can learn to privilege the latter over the former.

Collectively, these talks will highlight the interplay of psychology and philosophy in

constraining and testing current theories of explanation.
subs: Multiple Cognitive Structures: When and Why?|A Nonfictional Look at Mathematical Fictionalism|Engaging mental models in prediction and explanation to support learning in early childhood|Rational scientific theory discovery|Navigating the Conflict Between Science and Intuition|
authors: Sara Aronowitz, David Danks, Daniel Wilkenfeld, Richard Samuels, James Fritz, Elizabeth Bonawitz, Andrew Shtulman

name: ISHPSSB
abstract:
It is widely acknowledged among biologists that diverse living systems possess the capacity to

undergo regeneration, that is, they can under some circumstances repair and maintain themselves

following disturbance or damage. But because of the siloed nature of biological sciences, there is

little consensus about how processes of regeneration in different biological systems relate to one

another and little discussion about what can be learned from thinking across systems. This

symposium will provide a sustained analysis of the process of regeneration across biological

systems and scales. Bringing together philosophers currently investigating regeneration at

different scales, the aim of this symposium is to work towards answers to three crucial questions:

(i) What is regeneration? (ii) How does it compare with related concepts (such as resilience,

repair, growth, reproduction, and restoration)? (iii) Do the commonalities among regenerative

processes across living systems warrant a general theory of regeneration?
subs: Microbial community regeneration|Regeneration and cancer|Regeneration and the germline|The role of value attribution in coral regeneration|What is Regeneration in Biology, How Do We Know, and Why Should We Care?|
authors: Elis Jones, Andrew Inkpen, Lucie Laplane, Jane Maienschein, Kate MacCord

name: Philosophy of Social Science Roundtable
abstract:
Title: Race, Realism, and Social Scientific Methodology


Brief Abstract

This panel presents a series of talks centered on questions about the reality of race and of how we conceptualize disciplinary boundaries in the social sciences and adjacent areas. Ron Mallon investigates the objectivity of race in discussions in social ontology and the metaphysics of racial kinds. Mallon defends a role for racial identification in constituting a racial kind. Richard Lauer and Kareem Khalifa investigate the ontological status of race in light of the use of different measures of race in the social sciences. They argue for a thin realism about race that stands in competition with similar extant accounts. Tolbert and Genin investigate issues related to racial injustice in the use of algorithmic decision-making.


Justification of Importance to the Discipline

This symposium brings together philosophers who are engaged with philosophical questions about social scientific methodology and the reality of race. The authors are informed both by philosophical methods of understanding racial identity and with a concern for the methodology of the social sciences in pursuing questions about the nature of social kinds, especially race.

These questions are addressed using tools and insights from both the philosophy of science and the social sciences. In exploring each of these topics, the authors consider the status of race as social kind and the use of measures of race in the social sciences. In addressing these issues, the authors touch on a range of issues of importance to the philosophy of science. For example, there are questions about the existence of racial kinds to which Ron Mallon's paper contributes. Lauer and Khalifa bring together questions about measurement of race that are not often addressed in the philosophy of social science with questions about the ontology of race, thus contributing to the debate about scientific realism in the social sciences (a burgeoning debate that is receiving increased attention in the philosophy of social science literature). Finally, Tolbert and Genin also contribute to the empirical discussion of race, particularly where it contacts important and timely social concerns related to algorithmic decision-making.

In sum, all topics in this symposium address questions of central importance to the philosophy of science, especially the characterization of kinds deployed in the social sciences, the ontological import of measures in the social sciences.
subs: Against Predictive Invariance|Race, Objectivity, and Identity|Placeholder Realism about Race|||
authors: Richard Lauer, Kareem Khalifa, Ronald Mallon, Konstantin Genin, Alexander Tolbert

name: HOPOS
abstract:
Justifying inductive inferences

This session details how three natural philosophers -- Isaac Newton, Immanuel

Kant, and Charles Lyell -- thought of, and attempted to justify, inductive

inference. We see that each recognized the necessity of inductive inference for

scientific knowledge and, given this necessity, appealed to different core

concepts and principles to support it. These concepts/principles were both

methodological and substantive in kind, and highlight the various ways in which

inductive inference can be placed in the larger landscape of scientific

knowledge. In particular, we see how each of these philosophers brought in

additional resources to support an assumption of "uniformity of nature", thus

making it rational to presuppose some resemblance between present and future

or past experience, contrary to Hume's view that any such presupposition begs

the question.
subs: Fitter, Stronger, More General: The Multiple Aspirations of Newtonian Induction|Systematicity and Necessity in Kant’s Account of Particular Causal Laws|The Impact of Uniformitarianism on Geologic Induction|||
authors: Zvi Biener, Meghan Page, Katherine Dunlop

name: SPSP
abstract:
Pluralism and Integration in Human Cognitive and Behavioral Sciences

Philosophical accounts of the structure of science or of individual scientific disciplines (e.g., biology) have either endorsed a pluralism about scientific methods and explanatory models, or argued for integrative relations among fields and scientific ideas. An important case in point is the scientific study of human cognition and behavior, which because of its attempts to explain human aggression, sexuality, or gender differences has potential policy implications and has witnessed public controversy. Recently, Helen Longino has prominently argued for a strong pluralism, by maintaining that the different approaches to the study of human behavior cannot be integrated because they are incommensurable.

This symposium both takes a critical look at arguments for pluralism and analyzes novel cases from neuroscience and human behavior research, with the aim of revealing the presence of integrative relations or the potential for future integration. Our case studies range from behavior genetics to the neuroscience of face recognition, radical embodied cognitive science, and neuropsychiatry. Several of these philosophical cases have been developed based on collaborative interactions with cognitive and behavioral scientists.
subs: Toward a More Fine-Grained and Diverse Methodological Landscape  of Human Behavior Research|Convergent Perspectivism|Tales of Brains and Behavior:  A Pluralist Integration in Radical Embodied Cognitive Scienc|Integrating Methods in the Human Behavioral Sciences:  Implications for Scientific Pluralism||
authors: Ingo Brigandt, Vicente Raja, Kathryn Plaisance, Nina Atanasova

name: General Philosophy of Science
subs: The Evidence-Observation Distinction in Observation Selection Effects|Should We Get Rid of Theoretical Equivalence?|An Epistemic Account of Complex Phenomena|On Falsifying Empirical Contradictions||
authors: Matthew Maxwell, Marie Gueguen, Luis Felipe Bartolo Alegre, Steve Elliott

name: IHPST
abstract:
Nature of Science and the Communication of Biopolitics

During the COVID-19 crisis, unfortunately in most cases, both mainstream media and social media have reproduced one way of thinking: a politicized scientism. Science in all areas of research is characterized by open dialogue, conflicting arguments and multiple approaches in solving scientific problems. This image of science has disappeared from the public awareness for almost two years now. 

In the first paper of this symposium, an analysis of a series of on line videos and the comments that follow them as well as a variety of published on line articles where politicians, scientists and citizens present their ideas about the COVID-19 crisis is being presented. Results show that certain sequences in the structure of language and arguments concerning the aspects of the nature of science are present in the way politicians, scientists and citizens present their approach towards the COVID-19 crisis. 

On the one hand, those supporting the biopolitically accepted as correct agenda present minimum nature of the science content in their arguments, while completely miss the synthetic nature of science as a product and the nature of the evolution and the methodologies of science. Nevertheless, they overemphasize on elements concerning the nature of the science context and the interrelations between science and society that impose demands on scientific research and development coming from power centers and power figures of modern society, having a result on spreading bio-biased attitudes to the community. 

On the other hand, scientists and citizens engaged in public on line dialogues, present high input of the nature of the science content, of the synthetic nature of science as a product and of the nature of the evolution and the methodologies of science. In this case, the nature of the science context and the nature of the interrelations between science and society are brought forward in order to express the suppression of theories and research results that disagree with the biopolitically accepted as correct agenda to the extent of science being censored, while bioethics arguments point out the necessity of discussing about the nature of attitudes and values expressed though and fostered by science. 

In the second paper of the symposium, the case of Sweden is discussed. The Swedish authorities have referred heavily to 'evidence' and 'lack of evidence' when motivating the use or non-use of different regulations. For example, the Swedish state epidemiologist for a long time argued against the use of masks by the general public, due to lack of evidence of its usefulness to prevent the spreading of the COVID-19 virus. 

The reference to evidence/lack of evidence has been praised as well as criticized in the general debate involving the general public, politicians as well as scientists. The relationship between policy decisions and scientific knowledge is always complex. 

The debate on what actions should be taken in relation to COVID-19 would benefit from scientists, policy stakeholders, politicians and the general public clarifying pros and cons, risks and benefits, and the values guiding the choices between different possible actions. In addition, in issues such as what actions to take in relation to the COVID-19 virus, the situation is even more complex since "how the world 'is'" is subject to ongoing research – the evidence is not clear, nor is there agreement on what counts as evidence, or what constitutes reasonable evidence requirements. 

The paper suggests that science education should learn from the ongoing pandemic and reconsider simplistic notions of 'evidence' and 'investigations' described in secondary science textbooks, where processes of science are described as formulating a hypothesis, planning and performing an investigation and drawing conclusions, while 'messy' research processes and the nature of ongoing research are often left out. In addition, the relationship between ongoing research, evidence, and policy decisions should be discussed in more detail than what is usually the case, due to its importance for citizenship and everyday life. 

The third paper of the symposium discusses the fact that many individuals and students in particular, often do not have the tools to discern quality scientific information from tentative or poor quality information. They often fail to recognize pseudoscience, false information, or propaganda. Therefore, key foundational pedagogical concepts that are needed to develop the ability to evaluate scientific information are proposed such as: a) how inductive, deductive, and abductive reasoning work together to build scientific knowledge, b) how one can categorize types of scientific knowledge based on their tentativeness, c) how argument and evidence are codified by citations and referencing, d) how peer-review, publishing, and review articles are crucial in developing scientific consensus and e) how to find and access quality science information.

In the fourth paper of this symposium, the discussion focuses on the demand from society towards science education researchers to make proposals for digital educational material and teaching strategies that would help teachers understand and then be able to help their students learn what a virus triggered disease is and what medical research has to offer to tackle it. 

The need for a logical, distant from the current moment, objective approach and presentation in digital narratives created about diseases, their medicines and their vaccines, is presented coupled with the challenge designers and developers of digital narratives face to make an emotional over-ride, that is to find one or more tricks or perspectives that distract the audience from getting too emotionally involved. 

A digital narrative is presented in this paper that has been created based on history of science and history of medicine about diseases and attempts to point out elements of the nature of science about disease and treatment. 

The analysis of research data coming from interviews with teachers and students shows the impact of the developed digital narrative and opens the discussion on the educational demands of teachers and students for digital educational material and teaching approaches about diseases, medicines and vaccines especially in the current times when digital science narratives contribute to the on-line spread of information to citizens.

In the fifth paper of this symposium, attention is brought to the importance to identify what content is privileged around health and disease in science curricula, in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, pointing out the urgent task to help science teachers move from information to knowledge enabling action, exploring a multi-causal and multi-referential approach conveyed through narratives. The potential of the narrative format is examined in order to provide context, information and relations for students to explain aspects of pandemics from the past, present and future. 

Current education seems in competition with circulation of information facilitated by new technologies. The problem is that this "non-processed" information serves for little more than being used in non-productive ways. 

In this scenario, how can schools take profit of their position in society? 

Is school science preparing students to understand the links between ecosystemic degradation and the emergence of SARS-CoV-2? 

How can "standard" scientific content cope with socio-scientific issues such as whether "generalist" preventive measures are applicable in complex and sensitive contexts? 

What is the robustness of these "epistemic" operations based on a list of biomedical data on COVID-19? 

The paper examines the potential of scientific narratives to provide context, information and relations necessary for students to explain through theoretical models key aspects of pandemics aligning with the incorporation of an "integrated view" into school science and using narratives as a powerful vehicle to implement it in science classrooms.

authors: Fanny Seroglou, Lena Hansson, Lori Maramante, Agustín Adúriz-Bravo, Anna Letsi

name: Genetics & Causality in an Age of GWAS
abstract: Recent developments in genomic technology provide new insights into the genetic underpinnings of complex traits. Genome wide association studies (GWAS) have identified hundreds of small genetic variants that are statistically associated with complex traits such as intelligence, schizophrenia, and depression. Because effect sizes of individual variants are miniscule, researchers are now creating polygenic scores which sum the total effects of all statistically associated genetic variants. It is commonplace for practitioners in the sciences to refer to SNPs and polygenic scores as 'causal determinants' of traits of interest – but are these philosophically contentions interpretations justified? The goal of this symposium is to bring together an interdisciplinary team of scientists and philosophers to address old questions about causality and genetics in light of cutting edge technological advancements.
subs: Determining Genetic and Environmental Causes: the Case of Mendelian Randomization |Making Sense of SNP Heritability|Composition, Causation, Mechanism, and Genetic Explanation of Psychological Entities|Vera Causae in Behavior Genetics||
